channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Greenpeace Won’t Name Activists, Peru Says
item.description: Peruvian officials said on Monday that the environmental group Greenpeace had refused to hand over the names of activists who entered a protected area near the Nazca Lines, ancient etchings in the Peruvian desert.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and ANDREA ZARATE

item.title: 2 Military Bases in Syria Fall to Rebels
item.description: At least 43 deaths were reported in Monday’s assaults, which were led by the Nusra Front, and at least 15 Syrian soldiers were said to have been captured.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMAD GHANNAM

item.title: Interest Rate Rises to 17% in Russia
item.description: Western sanctions and the collapse in the price of oil have weighed on the economy and hurt the ruble.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and NEIL IRWIN
item.media:description: A neon sign advertised currency exchange rates in Moscow on Monday.

item.title: Gunman in Sydney Had Long History of Run-Ins With the Law
item.description: The gunman who seized hostages in downtown Sydney was known as a deeply troubled man with a pending case involving the murder of his former wife.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: A hostage ran to tactical response police officers after she escaped from a cafe under siege in Sydney, Australia, on Monday. Two other captives were killed.

item.title: Iraq’s Premier Has Narrowed Nation’s Divide
item.description: Haider al-Abadi, the prime minister of Iraq, has narrowed the sectarian divide in his country. But political enemies remain and a third of the country is beyond his control.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq, seen here in September, faces challenges from enemies in politics and on the battlefield.

item.title: Memo From Paris: A Plan to Limit Cars in Paris Collides With French Politics
item.description: The mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo, has proposed banning high-emission vehicles, particularly those that run on diesel, in the city’s center by 2020.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The mayor of Paris has proposed banning certain high-emissions vehicles, particularly those that run on diesel, from the city center by 2020. Praised by public health officials, the plan has been called elitist by its critics.

item.title: Op-Docs: ‘An Army for Afghanistan’
item.description: In this short documentary, Afghan soldiers struggle to fight an ongoing insurgency, as United States and NATO troops withdraw.
item.dc:creator: By SAEED TAJI FAROUKY and MICHAEL MCEVOY

item.title: World Briefing: Belgium: Unions Fight Austerity Policies
item.description: A general strike paralyzed air and rail traffic in Belgium and idled scores of companies across the country on Monday as trade unions capped a month of labor action against government austerity policies.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: NATO Voices Aviation Protest
item.description: NATO on Monday accused Russia of posing a danger to civil aviation in the Baltic region after Sweden protested that a Russian Air Force jet had flown too close to an airliner and had turned off one of its location instruments.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Denmark: A Claim to the North Pole
item.description: Scientific data shows that Greenland’s continental shelf is connected to a ridge beneath the Arctic Ocean, giving Denmark a claim to the North Pole and any energy resources beneath it, Denmark’s foreign minister has said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Militants Attack Military Base
item.description: Rebels from the Shabab militant group attacked a military base in southern Somalia early Monday, killing at least 10 soldiers and burning two military vehicles, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Security Council to Discuss North Korea
item.description: The United Nations Security Council agreed late Monday to consider the human rights situation in North Korea next week, paving the way for discussions on whether to refer the country to the International Criminal Court.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: News Analysis: Europe’s Impatience With Israel on Peace Talks Tests U.S. Diplomacy
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry tried to find a way forward as Palestinians pressed for a United Nations Security Council resolution and Europe drafted its own resolution.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, in Rome on Monday in an effort to advance the peace process.

item.title: Iran’s President Pledges to Face Down Forces Opposing a Nuclear Deal
item.description: Hassan Rouhani said he was determined to reach an agreement with the West in order to have sanctions lifted.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Turning #IllRideWithYou Into Real-World Action in Australia
item.description: After a gunman’s siege in Sydney set off fears of repercussions, an effort to show solidarity with Muslims was amplified on Twitter.
item.dc:creator: By NOAM COHEN

item.title: Obama Defends Progress Against Extremists
item.description: The president said that it had been made clear to ISIS that the United States would not back down and in the end, “we will get you.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: News Analysis: A Climate Accord Based on Global Peer Pressure
item.description: The agreement reached in Lima, Peru, would be a breakthrough in 20 years of efforts to create a global warming accord, but it falls short of what scientists say is needed.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Indian children carrying coal to a crushing machine in the state of Meghalaya. India is the world’s third largest carbon polluter.

item.title: France Says It Will Ban Uber’s Low-Cost Service in New Year
item.description: As Paris taxis staged a go-slow protest on Monday, an Interior Ministry spokesman said the ride-booking service would be prohibited as of Jan. 1.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY and MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: French taxi drivers protesting UberPop on Monday took part in a traffic slowdown along the Paris ring road.

item.title: Sydney Hostage Siege Ends With Gunman and 2 Captives Dead as Police Storm Cafe
item.description: The police burst into a downtown cafe where customers and employees had been captive for 16 hours, after officers reported hearing gunshots.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Police officials identified the hostage-taker as Man Haron Monis, a self-proclaimed sheikh with a criminal record.

item.title: German Leader Denounces Anti-Immigrant Surge
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel has denounced the demonstrations in Dresden, drawing 10,000 people last week, and said there was no place for xenophobia.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
